title: AboutX
text:
EndingLoneliness is an innovative online service platform designed to combat loneliness and foster meaningful connections by providing a safe space for individuals to share their everyday or personal challenges through group calls.

Targeting adults with demanding lifestyles, the platform offers a convenient and accessible solution for those who struggle to engage in traditional social interactions. Unlike therapy or mental health services, EndingLoneliness focuses on mutual understanding, listening, and support, without offering clinical or psychological advice.

title: Examples of presentations
text:
Here we can add links to presentations.
For now you can access the presentation by adjusting the URL below with your details
https://YOUR-GITHUB-ACCOUNT.github.io/NAME-OF-YOUR-GIT-REPO/tab-presentation/presentation1/presentation-example.html
Simply change my capitalized text for your: i) your github username
ii) the name of your github repo then copy the URL and paste it to visit the webpage.
The adjusted URL above should take you to an example of a simple Quarto presentation.

title: Sentiment Analysis of EndingLoneliness Participants Feedback
text:
Code
# Create a feedback dataset
feedback_data <- tibble(
  feedback_id = paste0("user_", 1:40),  # Create user_1 to user_40
  feedback_text = c(
    # Positive Feedback (24)
    "EndingLoneliness has truly changed my life. I’ve made meaningful connections and no longer feel isolated!",
    "I love the group calls! Talking to people who understand me has helped boost my confidence.",
    "The forum discussions are so engaging. It feels like a safe space to share my thoughts without judgment.",
    "I used to feel alone every evening, but thanks to this platform, I have a supportive community.",
    "This is the best platform I’ve found for connecting with like-minded individuals. Highly recommended!",
    "The real-time emotional insights helped me understand my own mental well-being better.",
    "I never thought virtual friendships could feel this real! The platform really fosters genuine connections.",
    "The interface is super easy to use, and I love how the platform encourages active participation.",
    "Since joining, I’ve gone from feeling lonely every day to feeling connected and supported.",
    "EndingLoneliness doesn’t just provide social interactions, it truly fosters a sense of belonging.",
    "I’ve met people from around the world and finally feel understood. This platform is amazing!",
    "The discussions on loneliness and mental health are really insightful and helpful.",
    "EndingLoneliness has given me a reason to look forward to my evenings. I love the community!",
    "I was skeptical at first, but after a month of using this, I’ve genuinely felt happier and more connected.",
    "Having a place where I can openly share my thoughts without fear of judgment is invaluable.",
    "The group calls are so well-moderated, and I feel safe opening up in them.",
    "I appreciate how easy it is to find like-minded individuals and have deep conversations.",
    "The platform helped me reconnect with socializing in a way I never thought possible.",
    "I used to be very shy, but participating in the discussions has made me more confident.",
    "EndingLoneliness is not just a platform, it’s a movement towards genuine human connection!",
    "I feel a sense of belonging here that I haven’t felt in years.",
    "The design of the platform makes it easy to engage, and I love how intuitive it is!",
    "I no longer feel like I’m battling loneliness alone. This platform has truly helped me.",
    "It’s comforting to know that there are so many people going through similar experiences.",
    
    # Neutral Feedback (10)
    "The platform is good, but I wish there were more features for one-on-one conversations.",
    "I like the community aspect, but sometimes I find it hard to keep up with discussions.",
    "The group calls are nice, but I don’t always find people I relate to.",
    "I appreciate what this platform is trying to do, but I’m not sure if it’s the right fit for me.",
    "The service is decent, but I haven’t noticed a significant change in my loneliness yet.",
    "I like the platform, but I wish there were more structured discussions.",
    "It would be great to have an option to filter group calls based on topics of interest.",
    "The platform is helpful, but sometimes discussions don’t go deep enough for me.",
    "I like being here, but I don’t engage as much as I probably should.",
    "It’s a nice concept, but I still haven’t made strong connections yet.",
    
    # Negative Feedback (6)
    "I wish there were more ways to interact outside of group calls.",
    "Sometimes I find the platform quiet when I really need someone to talk to.",
    "I tried using this for weeks, but I still feel disconnected from the conversations.",
    "Some discussions feel repetitive, and I struggle to find new insights.",
    "I was hoping for deeper engagement, but I often feel like I’m just a spectator.",
    "I expected more active engagement, but I often find myself in empty or inactive group calls."
  ) 
)

# Save the dataset to a CSV file
write_csv(feedback_data, "EndingLoneliness_Feedback.csv")




Code
feedback_data <- read_csv("EndingLoneliness_Feedback.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# Check the first few rows, and render as an html table
head(feedback_data, 20) %>%

Sentiment Overall
This table and graph below show the overall distribution of sentiment for the EndingLoneliness user feedback dataset.


Code
feedback_data <- read_csv("EndingLoneliness_Feedback.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)

# Dynamically categorize sentiment based on predefined distribution
feedback_data <- feedback_data %>%
  mutate(sentiment_category = case_when(
    row_number() <= 24 ~ "Positive",   # First 24 are positive
    row_number() > 24 & row_number() <= 34 ~ "Neutral",  # Next 10 are neutral
    TRUE ~ "Negative"  # Remaining 6 are negative
  ))

# Summarize sentiment counts
overall_sentiment <- feedback_data %>%
  count(sentiment_category) %>%
  mutate(Proportion = round(n / sum(n), 2)) %>%  # Calculate proportion
  rename(
    `Sentiment` = sentiment_category,
    `Count` = n
  )

# Display the summary table with formatting
overall_sentiment %>%
  kbl() %>%
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))





Sentiment
Count
Proportion




Negative
6
0.15


Neutral
10
0.25


Positive
24
0.60









Code
ggplot(overall_sentiment, aes(x = Sentiment, y = Proportion, fill = Sentiment)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", color = "black") +  # Bar plot with border
  geom_text(aes(label = Proportion * 100), vjust = -0.5, size = 4) +  # Add percentage labels
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Negative" = "red", "Neutral" = "green", "Positive" = "blue")) +  # Custom colors
  labs(title = "Sentiment Overall Distribution",
       x = "Sentiment",
       y = "Proportion (%)") +
  theme_minimal()  # Clean theme

title: Survey Analysis
Survey Analysis
text:
Factors to Numeric


Code
data <- data %>%
  mutate(
    loneliness_frequency = as.numeric(factor(loneliness_frequency, levels = c("Never", "Rarely", "Sometimes", "Often", "Always"), ordered = TRUE)),
    employment_status = factor(employment_status),
    relationship_status = factor(relationship_status),
    group_calls = factor(group_calls, levels = c("No", "Yes"), ordered = TRUE),
    sharing_comfort = as.numeric(factor(sharing_comfort, levels = c("Very uncomfortable", "Uncomfortable", "Neutral", "Comfortable", "Very comfortable"), ordered = TRUE)),
    real_name_usage = as.numeric(factor(real_name_usage, levels = c("Never", "Rarely", "Sometimes", "Often", "Always"), ordered = TRUE)),
    friend_count = as.numeric(factor(friend_count, levels = c("None", "1-3", "4-6", "6-8", "8 and more"), ordered = TRUE)),
    daily_meaningful_contacts = as.numeric(factor(daily_meaningful_contacts, levels = c("None", "1-5", "6-10", "11-20", "20 and more"), ordered = TRUE))
  )

title: Survey Analysis
text:
Age Distribution


Code
# Age distribution
data %>%
  mutate(age_group = cut(age, breaks = seq(26, 46, by = 10), include.lowest = TRUE)) %>%
  group_by(age_group) %>%
  summarize(mean_loneliness = mean(loneliness_frequency, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = age_group, y = mean_loneliness, fill = age_group)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", alpha = 0.8) +
  labs(
    title = "Mean Loneliness Frequency by Age Group",
    x = "Age Group",
    y = "Mean Loneliness Frequency",
    fill = "Age Group"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Survey Analysis
text:
Relationship


Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = relationship_status, y = loneliness_frequency, fill = relationship_status)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Relationship Status vs. Loneliness Frequency", x = "Relationship Status", y = "Loneliness Frequency") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Survey Analysis
text:
Income


Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = annual_income, y = daily_meaningful_contacts, fill = annual_income)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Annual Income vs. Daily Meaningful Contacts", x = "Annual Income", y = "Number of Meaningful Contacts") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Survey Analysis
text:
Friend


Code
data %>%
  group_by(friend_count) %>%
  summarize(mean_loneliness = mean(loneliness_frequency, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = friend_count, y = mean_loneliness, group = 1)) +
  geom_line(color = "blue", size = 1) +
  geom_point(color = "red", size = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Mean Loneliness Frequency by Friend Count",
    x = "Number of Friends",
    y = "Mean Loneliness Frequency"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

title: About
text:
EndingLoneliness is an innovative online service platform designed to combat loneliness and foster meaningful connections by providing a safe space for individuals to share their everyday or personal challenges through group calls.
Targeting adults with demanding lifestyles, the platform offers a convenient and accessible solution for those who struggle to engage in traditional social interactions. Unlike therapy or mental health services, EndingLoneliness focuses on mutual understanding, listening, and support, without offering clinical or psychological advice.

title: EndingLoneliness
text:
Feel heard, find connection, and combat loneliness—on your terms.
EndingLoneliness is an online platform offering group calls designed to foster connection and understanding. Anonymously share your thoughts and challenges in a safe space, and discover the power of mutual support. Join us and take the first step toward meaningful connections today.
“Join the Conversation, End the Loneliness”
“Where Connections Begin, Loneliness Ends”
“Because No One Should Feel Alone”
** appropriate for people seeking non-therapeutic connection. It distinguishes itself from mental health services by focusing on alleviating loneliness rather than addressing clinical issues.

title: Course overview
text:
What is a Dashboard?

Dashboards provide a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
They consolidate and arrange information on a single screen.

Key Characteristics of Effective Dashboards

Clarity: Information should be easy to read and interpret.
Accuracy: Data must be accurate and up-to-date.
Relevance: Content should align with user goals and needs.

title: Course overview
text: Definition by Stephen Few

title: Course overview
text:
The Role of Visual Design

Minimize distractions and unnecessary elements.
Use consistent layouts and formatting.
Apply thoughtful use of color and typography.

Best Practices for Dashboard Design

Avoid clutter: Only display essential information.
Prioritize data: Highlight key metrics and KPIs.
Use visual hierarchy: Direct the viewer’s focus to the most important elements.

title: Course overview
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Overloading the user with too much data.
Using overly complex or inconsistent designs.
Neglecting the importance of user testing.

What You Shoud Do

Focus on the needs and goals of the dashboard’s end-users.
Iteratively test and refine designs to improve usability.

title: Course overview
text:
Summary

Dashboards are powerful tools for decision-making.
Effective dashboards balance clarity, relevance, and visual appeal.
Avoid common pitfalls by focusing on user needs and testing designs.
